facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 736 of 1963 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 736 of 1963.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from Judgment and Order dated November 12, 1960 of Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Petition No. 265 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the Judgment and Order, dated November 12, 1960, of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Petition No. 265 of 1958.

facts.text: Petition for writ of certiorari moved in High Court of Madhya Pradesh to quash orders reducing pension granted to respondent Col. Lal Rampal Singh.

anchor.surface_text: This is the third case in the series and it arises out of a petition for a writ of certiorari moved in the High Court of Madhya Pradesh to quash -certain orders reducing the pension granted to the respondent Col. Lal Rampal Singh

facts.text: Pension granted by order of Ruler of Rewa before Rewa State merged in United State of Vindhya Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: by an order of the Ruler of Rewa before that State had merged in the United State of Vindhya Pradesh.

facts.text: Madhya Pradesh High Court took same view as in Nagod case Civil Appeal No. 738 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Madhya Pradesh took the same view as in the Nagod case  Civil Appeal No. 738 of 1963  in which judgment has been delivered earlier in the day.

facts.text: Respondent Col. Lal Rampal Singh held various offices in Government of Rewa.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent held various offices in the Government of Rewa.

facts.text: Ruler of Rewa made order on April 3, 1948 published in extraordinary issue of Rewa Raj Gazette.

anchor.surface_text: By an order made on April 3, 1948 and published in an extraordinary issue of the Rewa Raj Gazette

facts.text: Col. Lal Rampal Singh entered State service on 21st November 1922.

anchor.surface_text: the Ruler stated that Col. Lal Rampal Singh entered State service-on 21st November, 1922 and he is number anxious to retire.

facts.text: Col. Lal Rampal Singh put in service of more than 25 years up to April 3, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: and he is number anxious to retire. I find that he has. put in a service of more than 25 years up to date,

facts.text: Ruler allowed Col. Lal Rampal Singh to retire on full pension of Rs. 350 per month as special case with effect from April 3, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: and, as such, he is allowed to retire on a full pension of Rs. 350 per month of his last grade, as a special case with effect from the date of this order,

facts.text: Ruler condoned breaks in service of Col. Lal Rampal Singh.

anchor.surface_text: and the so-called breaks in his service, if there be any, are hereby companydoned.

facts.text: Respondent stated in petition that Ruler made Rewa State Pension and Gratuity Rules for grant of pension to Rewa State Civil Servants.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent in his petition stated that in Rewa the Ruler had made a set of rules, which was called Rewa State Pension and Gratuity Rules for grant of pension to Rewa State Civil Servants.

facts.text: Respondent stated Ruler was not bound by those Rules as sovereign Ruler.

anchor.surface_text: He however added that the Ruler was number bound by those Rules as he was a sovereign Ruler.

facts.text: Court found Ruler purported to act under Rewa State Rules based on terms of order.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us quite clear from the terms of the order that the Ruler purported to act under the Rewa State Rules. This appears from the reference in the order to full pension, companydonation of the breaks in his service and special case.

facts.text: Order granted respondent advance increments to justify full pension of Rs. 350 under Rules.

anchor.surface_text: This also appears from the fact that the Order granted the respondent certain advance increments which companyld only have been done to justify the full pension of Rs. 350 per month under the Rules.

facts.text: Under Rules, respondent entitled to smaller pension due to breaks without increments.

anchor.surface_text: Obviously, under the Rules the respondent would have been entitled to a smaller pension in view of the breaks and if the increments had number been granted.

facts.text: Order of April 3, 1948 is not a law but executive order passed in terms of Rules.

anchor.surface_text: That being so, it has to be held that the Order of April 3, 1948 is number a law but an executive order passed in terms of the Rules.

facts.text: Indian Union paid respondent in terms of the order up to March 27, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: as the Indian Union had paid the respondent in terms of the order up, to March 27, 1953,

facts.text: Respondent contended that if order not law, it was a grant accepted by payment till 1953.

anchor.surface_text: it was a grant and that as the Indian Union had paid the respondent in terms of the order up, to March 27, 1953, it must be deemed to have accepted that grant and it cannot number deprive the respondent of his right of property under the grant.

facts.text: Court held succeeding State competent to review the pension order even after payment.

anchor.surface_text: The succeeding State was hence companypetent to review the order even if it had paid the pension for sometime in terms of it.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, in our view, the appeal must be allowed and we order accordingly.
Appeal by special leave from the Judgment and Order, dated November 12, 1960, of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Petition No. 265 of 1958.
